awd_titl_txt: EAGER: QIA:  Optimal Synthesis Algorithms for Few-Qubit Fault-Tolerance
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing fast and efficient quantum compiling tools is critical to translate theoretical gains in quantum computation power to real world performance. Finding robust techniques to compile a quantum algorithm into the shortest sequence of standard universal quantum gates has profound impact to quantum computation in both near and long term. In the near term with the quantum hardware available currently or in the near future, halving the circuit lengths can mean the difference between success and failure of a computation task. In the long term, these techniques make fault-tolerant computing possible, which requires optimization of vast, complex circuits. The most viable approach to achieve this goal is to break up a large circuit into few-qubit subcircuits where reduction of the circuit length even merely by a constant factor manifests as an exponential improvement in computation performance. While optimal algorithms for single-qubit circuits have been well-understood, current efforts focus on solving the optimal compiling problem of two-qubit circuits. Achievement of this important milestone leading to further applications to larger circuits relies on a convergent effort with cross-disciplinary expertise, engaging students at both undergraduate and graduate levels in research and education programs, and participation of industrial collaborators.

The general quantum compiling problem being addressed here is as follows: given some unitary matrix representing the operation of a computation algorithm and a universal set of quantum gates, find a sequence of gates that either is equivalent to the unitary matrix (called exact synthesis) or approximates the unitary matrix within a desired precision (called inexact synthesis). The most efficient compiler is a circuit synthesis algorithm optimized by minimization of a given cost-metrics, such as the gate-count, especially for the gates that are difficulty to implement in a fault-tolerance manner. Optimal or at least nearly-optimal algorithms of two-qubit circuits for exact and inexact synthesis are achievable utilizing techniques based on number theory and matrix decomposition. It is estimated that the gate-count can be reduced by a constant-factor ranging roughly 1~10. Algorithms for either case have stand along values and are complementary to each other. They can be explored simultaneously and completed independently. Furthermore, these algorithms can be the basis to build synthesis techniques for even larger qubit-number circuits.

por.por_cntn:
A practical and efficient algorithm for compiling two-qubit quantum circuits has been development and implemented in the project. It was tested to show significant improvement over existing algorithms. It is expected that integrating this method with existing heuristic solvers to cover all quantum circuits of practical interest in the near future.

In classical computers, CPU's and GPU's work on a limited set of operations (gates) at the lowest level. Programmers, in general, are not required to work with this limited gate set as programming languages allow a much more expanded set of operations. In a similar fashion, quantum computers are restricted to a set of a few universal gates on the physical level while quantum algorithms are usually designed as quantum circuits and presented as general unitary operations. Bridging the gap are the compilers decomposing the unitary operations into a gate sequence over a universal gate set. The two main issues in developing quantum compiling tool are run time efficiency and gate sequence optimality (shortest sequence). With a commonly used Clifford + T gate set, the optimality translates to the least count of the T-gates in the sequence. A practical compiling task is to efficiently search for a gate sequence of lowest T-count starting from either a unitary operation specified as a matrix or a generating gate sequence. The project implemented and stress-tested an existing algorithm that can run in polynomial time and achieve suboptimal gate sequence starting from a given matrix. However, it has showed little advantage to shorten a given gate sequence.  To address these issues, the project has developed algorithms and code base that efficiently exhaust all shortest sequences to create a lookup table up to a maximum T-count allowed by user’s computer. Methods have also been introduced to reduce T-count independently of the generating sequence of higher maximum T-counts beyond the user’s computer’s capacity for exhaustive research. It is expected that integrating these methods with additional heuristic solvers will likely reliably outperform analytical methods for all quantum circuits that are of practical interest in the near term. It is also expected that the resulting efficient and practical compiling tools will significantly advance quantum computer’s applications on a broader scale. 

The project has offered training opportunities for students from a wide range of multidisciplinary backgrounds, including physics, mathematics, computer science, and electrical and computing engineering. These opportunities allow students to gain hands-on experience and develop critical skills in cutting-edge research areas. The contributions of student researchers, directly supported by the grant have been invaluable in driving the project's advancements and achieving its objectives. The activities supported by the project have attracted more students to the fields of quantum information and stimulated curriculum development interest among the faculty and support from the universality.
